page.title: List of incidents at independent amusement parks

revision.text:
This is a summary of notable incidents that have taken place at various independently owned [[amusement parks]], [[water parks]] or [[theme parks]]. This list is not intended to be a comprehensive list of every such event, but only those that have a significant impact on the parks or park operations, or are otherwise significantly newsworthy.
The term ''incidents'' refers to major accidents, injuries, deaths and significant crimes. While these incidents are required to be reported to regulatory authorities for investigation, attraction-related incidents usually fall into one of the following categories: *Negligence on the part of the park, either by ride operator or maintenance. *Caused by negligence on the part of the guest. This can be refusal to follow specific ride safety instructions, or deliberate intent to break park rules. * The result of a guest's known, or unknown, health issues. * [[Act of God]] or a generic accident (e.g. slipping and falling) that is not a direct result of an action on anyone's part. {{TOC right}}
<!--Do NOT add an incident without an independent third-party source. Per WP:BURDEN, the editor adding the information is responsible for providing the source to back up the change. Fan sites like themeparkreview.com and aggregator sites like rideaccidents.com are not considered reliable, although such sites often link to sources that may meet WP:RS. Personal accounts are not permitted per WP:V and WP:OR.-->
==Action Park== {{main article|Action Park}} * On July 8, 1980, a 19-year-old park employee was riding the ''Alpine Slide'' when his car jumped the track and his head struck a rock, killing him.<ref name="Water Ride Accidents"/> * On July 24, 1982, a 15-year-old boy drowned in the ''Tidal Wave Pool''.<ref name="Water Ride Accidents">[http://www.rideaccidents.com/water.html Water Ride Fatalities 1972-1997] at rideaccidents.com, retrieved January 12, 2006.</ref><ref>{{cite news | publisher = New York Times | title = Brooklyn Man Drowns in Pool At a Jersey Amusement Park | url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=940DE4DE1038F934A1575BC0A962948260&n=Top%2fReference%2fTimes%20Topics%2fSubjects%2fA%2fAmusement%20and%20Theme%20Parks | accessdate = 2006-08-26 | date=August 27, 1984}}</ref> * On August 1, 1982, a 27-year-old man from [[Long Island]] got out of his tipped [[kayak]] on the ''Kayak Experience'' to ride it. While doing so, he stepped on a grate that was either in contact with, or came too close to, a section of live [[wire|wiring]] for the underwater fans that somehow became exposed and he suffered a severe electric shock, which sent him into [[cardiac arrest]]. Several other members of his family nearby were also injured. He was taken to a hospital in nearby [[Warwick (village), New York|Warwick, New York]] where he died later of the shock-induced cardiac arrest.<ref name="Water Ride Accidents" /><ref name="Traction Park" /> The park at first disputed that the [[electric current]] caused his death, saying there were no [[burn (injury)|burns]] on his body, but the [[coroner]] responded that burns generally do not occur in a water-based [[electrocution]].<ref name="Traction Park" /> The ride was drained and closed for the investigation. Accounts differed as to the extent of the exposed wiring: the park said it was "just a nick," while others said it was closer to 8 inches (20 cm). The state's [[New Jersey Department of Labor|Labor Department]] found that the fan was properly maintained and installed and cleared the park of wrongdoing; however it also said that the current had the possibility to cause bodily harm under certain circumstances.<ref name="Water Ride Accidents" /> While the park said it was vindicated, it never reopened the ride, saying that people would be afraid to go on it afterwards.<ref name="Traction Park">Austin, Joanne; "Revisiting Traction ... Er, ''Action'', Park," ''[[Weird NJ]]'', October 2005, pages 20-24</ref> * In 1984, a fatal heart attack suffered by one visitor was unofficially believed to have been triggered by the shock of the cold water in the pool beneath the ''Tarzan Swing''. The water on the ride and in that swimming area was 50-60 °F (10-16 °C) while other water areas were in the 70-80 °F (21-27 °C) range more typical of swimming pools. The ''Tarzan Swing'' and the ''Cannonball ''ride in this area were operated by spring water.<ref name="Traction Park" /> * On August 27 of that year, a 20-year-old from [[Brooklyn]] drowned in the ''Tidal Wave Pool'' * On July 19, 1987, an 18-year-old from [[Queens]] drowned in the ''Tidal Wave Pool''.<ref name="Water Ride Accidents" /><ref>{{cite news | publisher = New York Times | title = 18-Year-Old Drowns At Amusement Park | url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B0DEFDA1630F933A15754C0A961948260&n=Top%2fReference%2fTimes%20Topics%2fSubjects%2fA%2fAmusement%20and%20Theme%20Parks | accessdate = 2006-08-26 | date=July 20, 1987}}</ref>
==Adventure Park at Grants Mill== * On May 10, 2018, the park management closed the park permanently and had attractions dismantled, after receiving 49 code violations from city and fire inspections. Most of the violations were related to exposed wiring. The park originally opened on October 5, 2013.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.al.com/news/birmingham/index.ssf/2018/05/adventure_park_in_irondale_clo.html |date=2018-05-11 |title=Safety violations shutter Adventure Park in Irondale |author=Eric Edgemon |publisher=AL.com }}</ref>
==Castles N' Coasters== {{main article|Castles N' Coasters}}
===Bumper Boats=== *On March 30, 2015, two young boys suffered burns when the bumper boat they were in caught fire.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.fox10phoenix.com/news/2-boys-face-long-painful-recovery-after-suffering-burns-on-castles-n-coasters-bumper-boat-ride|title=2 boys face, long painful recovery after suffering burns on Castles N' Coasters bumper boat ride - Story|publisher=KSAZ-TV|date=2015-03-30}}</ref>
===Splashdown=== {{main article|Splashdown (log flume)}} *On November 28, 2015, a 12-year-old boy was seriously injured after falling from a water log flume ride after standing up during the ride and required emergency brain surgery.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.azcentral.com/story/news/local/phoenix/breaking/2015/11/28/boy12-injured-ride-castles-n-coasters/76496462/|title=Boy, 12, injured on ride at Castles N' Coasters - AZCentral.com|publisher=The Arizona Republic|date=2015-11-28}}</ref>
==Coney Island== {{main article|Coney Island}}
===Himalaya=== * On June 12, 1999, a 17-year-old girl was killed and 8 others were injured when a car flew off the ride.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/06/13/nyregion/girl-is-killed-as-coney-island-ride-breaks.html|title=Girl Is Killed As Coney Island Ride Breaks - The New York Times|publisher=The New York Times|date=1999-06-13}}</ref>
===Polar Express=== * On August 5, 2007, a restraining lap bar broke causing an unidentified 15-year-old girl to fall out of her seat and into the center of the ride where she was briefly knocked unconscious. The ride was running in reverse at the time. The victim was taken to the hospital with head and leg injuries, and complaining of neck and back pain.<ref>{{cite news |url =http://www.nydailynews.com/news/2007/08/04/2007-08-04_girl_hurt_in_fall_from_coney_ride_as_saf-2.html |title = Girl hurt in fall from Coney ride as safety bar breaks |publisher = NY Daily News |date = 2007-08-04 |accessdate = 2007-08-07 | location=New York | first1=Jotham | last1=Sederstrom }}</ref>
===Coney Island Cyclone=== {{Main article|Coney Island Cyclone}} * On May 26, 1985, a 29-year-old man was killed while riding the ''Cyclone''. He stood up and struck his head on a crossbeam. * On August 23, 1988, a 26-year-old man was killed after falling from the ''Cyclone''. The man was a maintenance worker and was the only passenger at the time, riding in the back seat of the train during his lunch break. Apparently, he eluded the safety bar and was seen standing up as the train began its descent down the first hill. He fell {{convert|30|ft|m}} and landed on a crossbeam of a lower section of track. He was killed instantly. The ride was closed following the incident, but was reopened a day later after safety inspectors concluded that the ride was safe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rideaccidents.com/coasters.html|title=U.S. Roller Coaster Fatalities (1972-1997)}}</ref> *On May 19, 1998, The Cyclone was damaged by a fire at around 4:00 AM. * On July 31, 2007, a 53-year-old man broke several [[vertebrae]] while riding the ''Cyclone''. He died four days later due to complications from surgery.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brooklynpaper.com/stories/31/44/31_44_mm_cylone.html|title=Coney Island Cyclone Sending Some Riders to Hospital}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsday.com/news/local/wire/newyork/ny-bc-ny--cyclonelawsuit1030oct30,0,5043046.story|title=Family of man who died after Cyclone ride sues NYC}}</ref>
==Daytona Beach Boardwalk== {{main article|Daytona Beach Boardwalk}} ===Sand Blaster=== * On June 14, 2018, twelve guests were injured when the train derailed, with eight being taken to the hospital. Two of those guests fell {{convert|34|ft|m}} to the ground from the train that was dangling from the track.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-nation/wp/2018/06/15/daytona-beach-roller-coaster-derailed-injuring-six-riders/ |author=Kristine Phillips |title=Roller coaster derails, two riders fall 34 feet to the ground in Daytona Beach |publisher=Washington Post |date=2018-06-15 }}</ref>
==Dreamworld== {{main article|Dreamworld (Australian theme park)}}
===Thunder River Rapids Ride=== {{main article|Thunder River Rapids Ride incident}} *On October 25, 2016, four people—two men aged 35 and 38, and two women aged 32 and 42—were killed when the raft they were riding hit another stopped raft, causing it to flip. Eyewitness accounts noted that the water level in the channel had dropped prior to the incident, but the drop did not trigger a sensor that would have stopped the ride. Investigators believe that the occupied raft was pushed up onto a stopped raft by a conveyor belt, at first mounting the stopped raft then flipping over. Of the six passengers aboard the raft, two children—aged 10 and 12—were ejected from the raft but survived, while the two men were believed to be crushed under the raft and the two women were trapped underneath the conveyor belt. Dreamworld officials stated that the ride had just passed its annual inspection in September.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-10-25/four-people-dead-ride-at-dreamworld-gold-coast/7963880|title=Dreamworld: Four people killed on Thunder River Rapids ride at Gold Coast theme park|publisher=ABC News|date=October 25, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://au.news.yahoo.com/a/33001335/one-person-seriously-injured-at-dreamworld/#page1|title=Four dead in Gold Coast tragedy: Dreamworld closed indefinitely|author=Niamh Hannon|work=Yahoo! 7 News|publisher=Yahoo!|date=October 25, 2016|accessdate=October 25, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.9news.com.au/national/2016/10/26/20/25/investigators-piecing-together-how-fatal-accident-unfolded|title=Dreamworld tragedy: Investigators piecing together how fatal accident unfolded|work=9news.com.au|publisher=Nine Digital PTY, Ltd.|date=October 26, 2016|accessdate=October 26, 2016}}</ref> On November 9 [[Ardent Leisure]] chief executive [[Deborah Thomas]] announced that the ride would be permanently closed and demolished.<ref name="rapidsride">{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-11-09/dreamworld-theme-park-demolish-ride-gold-coast/8007870 |title=Dreamworld's Thunder River Rapids Ride to be demolished after theme park deaths |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |work=ABC News |date=9 November 2016 |accessdate=9 November 2016}}</ref>. The park was closed for six weeks following the accident. Further investigation indicates that the incident occurred when one of two water pumps on the attraction failed.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-06-18/dreamworld-tragedy-inquest-begins-thunder-river-rapids-deaths/9875012 |date=2018-06-17 |title=Dreamworld fatal accident: Coronial inquest into deaths on rapids ride begins |author=Ellie Sibson |publisher=ABC }}</ref>
== Dutch Wonderland == {{main article|Dutch Wonderland}}
===Sky ride=== *On July 19, 2008, a 44-year-old woman from [[Ann Arbor, Michigan]] lost about a centimeter off the tip of her left index finger when it was caught in the safety bar.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://articles.lancasteronline.com/local/4/224760 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20080722224612/http://articles.lancasteronline.com/local/4/224760 |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 2008-07-22 |title = Woman loses part of finger on park ride |publisher = Lancaster Newspapers |date = 2008-07-20 |accessdate = 2008-08-15 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.wgal.com/news/16940255/detail.html |title = Woman Loses Fingertip At Amusement Park |publisher = WGAL-TV Lancaster, PA |date = 2008-07-21 |accessdate = 2008-08-15 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110717045603/http://www.wgal.com/news/16940255/detail.html |archivedate = 2011-07-17 |df = }}</ref>
==Expoland (Japan)== {{main article|Expoland}}
===Fujin Raijin II=== * On May 5, 2007, a 19-year-old from [[Higashiomi, Shiga|Higashiomi]], [[Shiga Prefecture|Shiga]] was killed and nineteen other guests were injured when the ''Fujin Raijin II'' derailed at Expoland in [[Suita]], [[Osaka Prefecture|Osaka]]. An investigation revealed that the ride derailed due to a broken axle. None of the ride vehicle's axles had been replaced for fifteen years.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://mdn.mainichi-msn.co.jp/national/news/20070507p2a00m0na014000c.html |title=Amusement park failed to replace axles of roller coaster in fatal crash for 15 years |publisher=Mainichi Interactive/MSN |date=2007-05-07 |accessdate=2007-05-07 }}{{dead link|date=January 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Following this accident, similar coasters at other Japanese parks were voluntarily shut down and inspected to see if they could have the same axle flaw.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://mdn.mainichi-msn.co.jp/national/news/20070507p2a00m0na011000c.html |title=Kumamoto amusement park shuts down roller coaster after deadly Osaka accident |publisher=Mainichi Interactive/MSN |date=2007-05-07 |accessdate=2007-05-07 }}{{dead link|date=January 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Expoland was cited by authorities for faulty maintenance when similar axle cracks were found on a second train a month later.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.inform.kz/showarticle.php?lang=eng&id=152953 |title=Cracked axle found on roller coaster |publisher=Kazinform |date=2007-06-25 |accessdate=2007-06-26 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928020437/http://www.inform.kz/showarticle.php?lang=eng&id=152953 |archivedate=2007-09-28 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> On July 15, 2008, three former Expoland employees—the director and administrative manager, the head of facility and business department, and the head of the technical division—agreed with the allegation of professional negligence and violating Building Standards Law. They admitted to purposefully postponing the coaster's regular inspection, even though a visible crack was noticed months earlier, as well as submitting a false inspection report.<ref>{{cite news |url =http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/national/20080715TDY02306.htm |title = Expoland ex-officials take blame for accident |publisher = The Yomiuri Shimbun |date = 2008-07-15 |accessdate = 2008-07-15 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
==Galaxyland== {{Main Article|Galaxyland}}
===Mindbender=== {{Main Article|Mindbender (Galaxyland)}} *On June 14, 1986, the fourth car of the yellow train derailed before encountering the third and final loop. The train failed to clear the loop and slid backwards fishtailing wildly and crashing into a concrete pillar. Damage from the derailment caused the lap bars to disengage at some point during the ride, throwing its four passengers at least 25 feet (7.6 m) to the floor below. Three passengers died in the incident, while a fourth was critically injured.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://globalnews.ca/news/3140402/survivor-of-1986-west-edmonton-mall-roller-coaster-crash-wants-tribute/ |title=Survivor of 1986 West Edmonton Mall roller-coaster crash wants tribute |publisher=The Canadian Press |author=Chris Purdy |date=2016-12-21 }}</ref> About 19 others were treated for less severe injuries at the nearby Misericordia Community Hospital. An investigation determined that bolts on the left wheel assembly worked loose causing the accident, and that design flaws by Schwarzkopf along with a lack of maintenance by the mall were likely to blame. When Mindbender reopened in January 1987, the trains were redesigned. Existing four-car trains were converted to three-car trains (reducing seating capacity from 16 to 12), and anti-roll back features were installed. The lap bar restraint was retained, but seat belts and shoulder headrests were added.
==Go Bananas== ===Guest altercations=== *On August 25, 2018, a brawl occurred inside the amusement center which happened on the weekend between two women during one of their child's birthday party. All of the footage from the fight was recorded on a cellphone before being uploaded on Facebook and other online media platforms two days later and went viral on the internet. Many people demanded the place to be closed permanently with a petition that is currently being held. Over 3,000 people have signed.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nbcchicago.com/news/local/go-bananas-fight-goes-viral-sparks-petition-to-shut-down-venue-491853621.html|title='Go Bananas' Fight Goes Viral, Sparks Petition to Shut Down Venue - NBC Chicago|publisher=WMAQ-TV|date=2018-08-27}}</ref>
===Python Pit=== *On April 2, 2011, a 3-year-old boy from [[Dolton, Illinois]] was killed while he was riding the kiddie coaster with his twin brother at the indoor amusement center. He was struck by a moving train when he fell off the ride about to 3 or 4 feet after he was ejected from his safety restraints and was wedged between one of the cars. The boy was pronounced dead on scene according to the Cook County Medical Examiner's office after being taken to a nearby hospital and he died from his injuries. His twin brother was not injured in the accident and was able to get off the ride safely once the train returned to the station. The facility was shut down for a brief time shortly after, but later re-opened along with the ride to make sure it was running properly.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nbcchicago.com/news/local/Boy-3-Dies-on-Roller-Coaster-at-Go-Bananas-Norridge-Family-Amusement-Center-119143109.html|title=Boy, 3, Dies on Indoor Roller Coaster - NBC Chicago|publisher=WMAQ-TV|date=2011-04-03}}</ref>
==Water Park of America== {{main article|Water Park of America}} ===Minneapolis location=== * On May 22, 2006, a 39-year-old man from [[Lakeville, Minnesota]] suffered a bruised [[spinal cord]] while attempting to ride the ''[[FlowRider]]'' wave ride on a [[bodyboard|boogie board]]. As a result, the victim had two titanium screws and a plate inserted into his neck to stabilize [[vertebrae]] and relieve pressure on his spinal cord. Doctor reports stated that the victim was almost paralyzed, but regained some movement in his limbs shortly after surgery.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thescizone.com/news/articles/686/1/Lakeville-mans-spinal-cord-bruised-in-water-park-accident/Page-1.html |title=Lakeville man's spinal cord bruised in water park accident |publisher=AP |date=2006-05-26 |accessdate=2007-01-05 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061111060939/http://www.thescizone.com/news/articles/686/1/Lakeville-mans-spinal-cord-bruised-in-water-park-accident/Page-1.html |archivedate=2006-11-11 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> ==Hersheypark== {{main article|Hersheypark}} * In 2006, of the 1.4 million visitors to the park, 55 people were injured at Hersheypark.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.pennlive.com/printer/printer.ssf?/base/news/1166452806204870.xml&coll=1 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070928020059/http://www.pennlive.com/printer/printer.ssf?%2Fbase%2Fnews%2F1166452806204870.xml&coll=1 |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 2007-09-28 |title = Amusement parks report more thrills, fewer spills |publisher = The Patriot-News |date = 2006-12-18 |accessdate = 2006-12-18 |df = }}</ref>
==Holiday World & Splashin' Safari== {{main article|Holiday World & Splashin' Safari}}
===The Raven=== * On May 31, 2003, a 32-year-old female from [[New York City]], died after falling out of ''The Raven'' roller coaster. The victim was visiting the park to attend "Stark Raven Mad 2003", an event hosting roller coaster enthusiasts from around the United States. At approximately 8:00 pm, the victim and her fiancé boarded ''The Raven'' in the last row of the train. Following a safety check of her lap bar and seat belt by a ride operator, the train left the station. Multiple witnesses reported that they saw her "virtually standing up" during the ride's initial and subsequent drops. During the ride's {{convert|69|ft}} drop, also called the fifth drop, she was ejected from the car and onto the tracks. When the train returned to the station, the victim's fiancé, ride operators, and a passenger who was a doctor ran back along the tracks, at which point they found her lying under the structure of the roller coaster at the fifth drop. The doctor, aided by park medical personnel, began [[Cardiopulmonary resuscitation|CPR]] until an ambulance arrived. The victim was pronounced dead en route to the hospital.<ref>{{cite web|title=Prosecutor's Report|url=http://www.masstort.org/Downloads/HW/finalpros.pdf|publisher=Spencer County Prosecutor's Office|accessdate=15 November 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111004213338/http://www.masstort.org/Downloads/HW/finalpros.pdf|archive-date=2011-10-04|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
:An investigation following the accident showed that the safety restraints were working properly and that there were no mechanical deficiencies on the roller coaster. Additionally, the victim's seatbelt was found undone when the train returned to the station.<ref>http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/victim-opened-belt-stood-coaster-article-1.664737</ref> A subsequent 2005 [[lawsuit]] filed by the family against Holiday World and the [[Philadelphia Toboggan Company]], the manufacturer of the coaster train, was settled out of court in 2007. Terms of the settlement were not disclosed.<ref>{{cite web|title=Fellner v. Holiday World Details|url=http://masstort.org/site/index.php?id=12|accessdate=15 November 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111001075907/http://masstort.org/site/index.php?id=12|archive-date=2011-10-01|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Fellner v. Holiday World Settles|url=http://masstort.org/site/index.php?id=124|accessdate=15 November 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111001075856/http://masstort.org/site/index.php?id=124|archive-date=2011-10-01|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
===Lawnmowing accident=== *On May 27, 2006, a 20-year-old male park employee from [[Birdseye, Indiana|Birdseye]], [[Indiana]] died after being pinned under the lawn mower he was using. The man was a supervisor for the park's grounds department. The employee was working alone, mowing an area with some inclines outside the east side of the park when the incident occurred, though the park refused to speculate on exactly what might have happened. The man was found by another employee, who was then able to help lift the lawn mower off the victim with the help of other employees. Park [[emergency medical technician]]s and [[Spencer County, Indiana|Spencer County]] [[Emergency medical services|EMS]] summoned a [[Air ambulance|medical helicopter]] from [[St. Mary's Hospital and Medical Center]] in [[Evansville, Indiana|Evansville]], [[Indiana]], but the employee was pronounced dead before it arrived.<ref>{{cite web|title=Holiday World Employee Laid to Rest|url=http://www.14news.com/Global/story.asp?s=4959627&clienttype=printable|publisher=NBC 14 WFIE|accessdate=17 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Non-ride Related Death at Holiday World|url=http://www.themeparkreview.com/forum/viewtopic.php?t=25499|publisher=Evansville Courier & Press/Theme Park Review|accessdate=17 May 2013}}</ref>
===The Wave=== *On July 4, 2007, at 11:00 a.m., a 29-year-old female from [[Fort Wayne, Indiana|Fort Wayne]], [[Indiana]] died after collapsing near the edge of ''The Wave, ''falling face-down into two inches of water. Lifeguards immediately responded and pulled her out, then attempted to revive her with help from park medical personnel. Resuscitation attempts continued as the victim was transported by ambulance to [[Jasper, Indiana|Jasper]] Memorial Hospital, where she died. An [[autopsy]] determined the cause of death to be [[Heart failure|congestive heart failure]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Name Released in Holiday World Death|url=http://www.courierpress.com/news/2007/jul/06/holiday-world-visitor-died-of-heart-failure-say/|publisher=Evansville Courier & Press|accessdate=15 November 2011}}</ref>
===Bahari River=== *On June 20, 2009, a filter pump on ''Bahari River'' malfunctioned, sending twenty-four guests and employees to the hospital. At 6:25 pm, the pump, which was turned off at the time, was turned back on. The pump surged, forcing a stronger than usual concentration of [[Sodium hypochlorite|liquid bleach]] and [[hydrochloric acid]] into the water. Twenty-four people, including park staff and medical personnel, complained of troubled breathing and [[nausea]]. They were given [[oxygen]] at the park before being transported to [[Jasper, Indiana|Jasper]] Memorial Hospital for treatment. All were treated and released that evening. It was later determined that an interlock system designed to prevent chemical feeders from pumping chemicals into the water when the pump was turned off had malfunctioned.<ref>{{cite web|title=Two dozen treated at Holiday World|url=http://www.courierpress.com/news/2009/jun/20/two-dozen-treated-holiday-world/|publisher=Evansville Courier & Press|accessdate=15 November 2011}}</ref>
===Bomb scare===
*On June 30, 2016, a suspicious unattended backpack was found, causing an evacuation of the entire park.<ref>{{cite web|title=Holiday World and Spashin’ Safari evacuated due to ‘suspicious’ backpack|url=http://fox59.com/2016/06/30/holiday-world-and-spashin-safari-evacuated-due-to-suspicious-backpack/|publisher=FOX 59|accessdate=1 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Suspicious bag forced Holiday World evacuation|url=http://www.courier-journal.com/story/news/local/indiana/2016/07/01/suspicious-bag-forced-holiday-world-evacuation/86590654/|publisher=The Courier-Journal|accessdate=1 July 2016}}</ref>
==Houston Livestock Show and Rodeo== {{main article|Houston Livestock Show and Rodeo}}
===Power outage=== *On February 28, 1999, 15 people were stranded on a ride for a few minutes before they were able to get off. No serious injuries were reported, although six people complained of dizziness and neck pain.<ref name="RideAccidents.com">RideAccidents.com</ref>
===Hi-Miler=== *On March 20, 2011, a lap bar on the ''Hi-Miler'' roller coaster at the Houston Livestock Show and Rodeo suddenly unlocked, causing a 47-year-old male guest to fall more than {{convert|28|ft|m}} from the roller coaster. The malfunction was caused by a single screw, which was supposed to keep the lock pin in place and the lap bar locked. The victim sustained serious chest and head injuries, and later died as a result of his injuries.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.denenapoints.com/caseresult/2700000-settlement-family-man-killed-28-foot-fall-roller-coaster-houston-livestock-show-rodeo/ |title = Deadly Roller Coaster fall at Houston Liestock Show and Rodeo |publisher = Denena and Points, P.C. |date = 2012-04-20 |accessdate = 2014-04-20 }}</ref>
==Idlewild== {{main article|Idlewild and Soak Zone}}
===Rollo Coaster=== * On August 12, 2016, a 3-year-old boy was injured when he fell out of the coaster train. He was airlifted to a nearby hospital in Pittsburgh.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/08/11/us/pennsylvania-child-falls-off-roller-coaster/|title=Boy falls off Pennsylvania roller coaster|publisher=''[[CNN]]''|date=12 August 2016|accessdate = August 12, 2016 |author1=Steve Visser |author2=Lauren Del Valle}}</ref>
==Jazzland== {{For|incidents at the former Jazzland|Incidents at Six Flags parks#Six Flags New Orleans}}
==Kennywood== {{main article|Kennywood}}
===King Kahuna=== *On July 6, 2008, twenty riders were stranded upside down for ten minutes when the ''King Kahuna'' ride malfunctioned and unexpectedly stopped for an undetermined reason.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://kdka.com/local/Kennywood.King.Kahuna.2.764903.html |title='King Kahuna' Closed During Probe Of Malfunction |publisher=KDKA |date=2008-07-07 |accessdate=2007-07-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080709070833/http://kdka.com/local/Kennywood.King.Kahuna.2.764903.html |archivedate=2008-07-09 |df= }}</ref> One of the riders sued Kennywood for negligence, claiming that the ride caused spinal damage. On March 26, 2013, a jury ruled that the plaintiff had a pre-existing spinal condition, and that any injury she suffered was not due to the ride.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.wpxi.com/news/news/local/jury-rules-kennywood-ride-didnt-cause-riders-spina/nW4cY/ |title = Jury rules Kennywood ride didn’t cause rider’s spinal damage |publisher = WPXI |date = 2013-03-26 |accessdate = 2013-03-26 }}</ref>
===Popover===
*On August 7, 1968, a 15-year-old girl from [[Monongahela, Pennsylvania]] died and a 15-year-old-girl from [[Monessen]], [[Pennsylvania]] fractured both wrists after falling {{convert|30|ft|m}} from the ride when a bolt supporting one of the cages broke, causing the cage to collapse, dropping the girls to the ground.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1129&dat=19680808&id=TA5ZAAAAIBAJ&sjid=cWwDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2070,1008503&hl=en|title=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette - Google News Archive Search|publisher=}}</ref>
===Thunderbolt=== *On May 17, 1968, a 15-year-old boy from [[Greensburg, Pennsylvania]], fell to his death after standing up on the ride.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/19231113/death_on_kennywood_thunderbolt/|title=Death on Kennywood Thunderbolt. - Newspapers.com|publisher=|date=1968-05-17|accessdate=2018-09-06}}</ref> *On July 9, 1999, there was an accident on the ''Thunderbolt'' when operators failed to brake an incoming train, which collided with the train being loaded. 35 people were injured in the crash. After the accident, the headlights on the cars were partially removed because the electrical system did not hold up well against the vibration of the cars.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.old.post-gazette.com/reigonstate/19990709kenny1.asp|title=35 hurt on Kennywood coaster - Pittsburgh Post Gazette|publisher=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|date=1999-07-09|accessdate=2018-08-06}}</ref>
===The Whip=== *On May 31, 2002, a 29-year-old female guest from [[Monroeville, Pennsylvania]] was killed when the roof of ''The Whip'' collapsed during a [[microburst]]. On July 20, 2007, a trial jury awarded the victim's family US $1.945 million.<ref> {{cite news |url=https://www.old.post-gazette.com/localnews/20020601kenny0601p3.asp |title=Kennywood Park witnesses describe Chaos at Whip ride |publisher= |date=2002-06-01 |accessdate=2002-06-01}} </ref>
===Raging Rapids=== *On July 2, 2017, a man's eye was infected by a [[Microsporidia|microspordia parasite]]. The man complained the water was "dirty, stagnant, and sludge-like". He underwent surgery to get the parasite removed, but the operation was unsuccessful. The man went blind. The man plans to sue Kennywood for $35,000. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.post-gazette.com/local/south/2017/11/29/Kennywood-Raging-Rapids-eye-eating-parasite-lawsuit-Pittsburgh-Alleghany-county-amusement-park/stories/201711290212|title=Lawsuit alleges Kennywood's Raging Rapids gave man eye-eating parasite|publisher=}}</ref>
===Thomas Railroad=== *On July 31, 2018, soon after the grand opening of the area titled ‘Thomas Town,’ the re-themed railway train derailed. No guests were hurt, but the ride closed for examination and repairs.<ref name="thomastrain2018">{{cite news |url=https://www.wtae.com/article/thomas-town-ride-goes-off-the-tracks-at-kennywood/22612802 |title=Thomas Town ride temporarily closed as maintenance investigates after second derailment this week |publisher=WTAE-TV |date=2018-08-02 }}</ref> * On August 2nd, 2018, the Thomas Town train derailed for a second time in a week. No injuries were reported.<ref name="thomastrain2018"/>
==Kentucky Kingdom== {{Main article|Kentucky Kingdom}}
===Vampire=== *On April 7, 1999, the ride stranded 27 people nearly {{convert|60|ft|m}} in the air for as much as four hours. For the inconvenience, the staff gave the riders stuffed animals and water bottles. It was caused by a malfunction in the ride's automatic braking system. *On May 29, 1999, the ride stranded 26 people for four hours. It was nearly a mirror image of the incident that happened one month prior. Firemen were able to get the riders off using cherry pickers, and nobody was injured.<ref name="RideAccidents.com"/>
===Starchaser=== *On July 26, 1994, five unidentified riders were injured when two cars collided in an incident that inspectors said was due to operator error. After the accident, the park filed suit against [[Louisville, Kentucky]] television station WHAS-TV for reporting on the accident in a misleading and malicious manner. The station had inaccurately reported that the ride malfunctioned, was dangerous, and that the park had removed a "key component" of the ride. The station lost the lawsuit and was ordered to pay US$3 million to the park.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.gannett.com/go/newswatch/2005/september/nw0909-8.htm |title = Kentucky Supreme Court Reinstates $3 Million Defamation Verdict |publisher = Gannett |date = 2005-09-09 |accessdate = 2007-06-21 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101030163559/http://gannett.com/go/newswatch/2005/september/nw0909-8.htm |archivedate = 2010-10-30 |df = }}</ref>

|deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> On July 3, 2007, the victim's family released a statement stating that doctors reattached her right foot. However, her left leg was amputated below the knee.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.wlky.com/news/13616751/detail.html |title = Six Flags Maiming Victim Has One Foot Reattached |publisher = WLKY |date = 2007-07-03 |accessdate = 2007-07-04 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120213235530/http://www.wlky.com/news/13616751/detail.html |archivedate=2012-02-13 }}</ref> :On July 13, 2007, the victim's family filed a lawsuit for unspecified damages, claiming that the park did not properly maintain the ride.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.upi.com/Top_News/2007/07/13/Theme-park-sued-over-foot-severing/UPI-58711184377225/?st_rec=88591227329655 |title = Theme park sued over foot-severing |publisher = UPI |date = 2007-07-13 |accessdate = 2007-07-15 }}</ref> On November 29, 2007, a judge in the Jefferson Circuit Court said that Six Flags could dismantle the ride beginning February 1, 2008. As of December 1, 2007, the ride's cable was still in storage awaiting lab tests.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.courier-journal.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20071129/NEWS01/71129060/1008 |title = Kentucky Kingdom to tear down ride that maimed girl |publisher = The Courier-Journal |date = 2007-11-29 |accessdate = 2007-12-01 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> On May 30, 2008, the Kentucky Department of Agriculture released their report on the accident, concluding that the accident was due to a faulty cable, as well as poor operator training in that if the ride operators had acted to shut down the ride in a timely manner, guests would only have suffered minor cuts. The report also stated that the park was fined $1,000 for not properly maintaining the ride.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.wkyt.com/news/headlines/19409284.html |title = Faulty Cable, Operator Blamed For Thrill Ride Accident |publisher = WKYT |date = 2008-05-30 |accessdate = 2008-05-30 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303225850/http://www.wkyt.com/news/headlines/19409284.html |archive-date= 2016-03-03 }}</ref> On November 21, 2008, a settlement to "provide lifetime care" was reached between Kentucky Kingdom and the victim's family.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.courier-journal.com/article/20081121/NEWS01/81121032/-1/NLETTER05?source=nletter-breakingnews |archive-url = https://archive.is/20130120044809/http://www.courier-journal.com/article/20081121/NEWS01/81121032/-1/NLETTER05?source=nletter-breakingnews |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 2013-01-20 |title = Kentucky Kingdom settles with Lasitter family |publisher = The Courier-Journal |date = 2008-11-21 |accessdate = 2008-11-21 }}</ref>
===T3=== *On June 2, 2018, two trains collided in the station<ref name="2018 incident">{{cite news|title=T3 roller coaster at Kentucky Kingdom closes for investigation|url=http://www.wrdb.com/story/38333795|accessdate=June 2, 2018|date=June 2, 2018}}</ref>. Five guests were treated at the park's health center, and one of those riders were subsequently taken to the hospital. The ride reopened two days later, but running only one train instead of two, pending further investigation. A park spokesperson stated that they believe the accident may have been caused due to a lightning strike that may have affected the coaster's electronic systems.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.wkyt.com/content/news/Roller-coaster-closed-at-Kentucky-park-after-cars-bump-484428021.html |date=2018-06-03 |publisher=WKYT |author=Associated Press |title=Roller coaster at Kentucky park reopens after cars bump }}</ref>
==Knoebels== {{main article|Knoebels}}
*On July 6, 2011, a young boy was found face down in the pool. By the time the ambulance arrived, lifeguards performed [[CPR]] and were successful at getting a heartbeat and the boy breathing on his own. He died later at a local hospital from trouble breathing. It was later determined that the child suffered from a pre-existing heart condition that is associated with [[Noonan syndrome]].<ref>{{cite news| last=Pennlive| title=Boy who died at Knoebels Amusement Park had undiagnosed heart problem, coroner says| url=http://www.pennlive.com/midstate/index.ssf/2012/03/boy_who_died_at_knoebels_amuse.html| accessdate=2012-03-24| newspaper=Patriot News| date=March 24, 2012 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120906191740/http://www.pennlive.com/midstate/index.ssf/2012/03/boy_who_died_at_knoebels_amuse.html |archive-date=2012-09-06}}</ref> *On July 16, 2016, another young boy died after he was found unresponsive in the swimming pool. He was rushed to a nearby hospital where he was pronounced dead. The incident may have been caused by a pre-existing medical condition.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://time.com/4409627/knoebels-amusement-resort-drowning-boy/|title=8-Year-Old Boy Drowns in Pool at Knoebels Amusement Resort|publisher=''[[TIME]]''|date=12 August 2016|accessdate = August 12, 2016 |author=Melissa Chan}}</ref>
===Scenic Skyway=== * On June 13, 2003, a man was seriously injured in a {{convert|30|ft|m|adj=on}} fall from the ''Scenic Skyway'' chairlift ride at Knoebels Amusement Park. The man was a member of a [[group home]] for [[mental illness|mentally disabled]] people and was riding alone. He was airlifted to a local hospital and recovered. The ride had opened just two weeks prior to the accident. Inspectors found no problems with the ride.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.rideaccidents.com/2003.html#jun13 |title = Man falls from Scenic Skyway at Knoebels |publisher = Ride Accidents |date = 2003-06-13 |accessdate = 2007-01-04 }}</ref>
===Speed Slide=== * On March 2, 1999, an attorney representing two girls who sustained injuries while riding a water slide at a Pennsylvania amusement park [[discovery (law)|discovered]] a history of complaints of injuries made by riders after they had ridden the same ride. Fifteen injuries had been reported to the Pennsylvania Department of Agriculture's Bureau of Ride and Measurement Standards in recent years, including six reports of injuries to riders' genital areas. The ''Speed Slide'', also known as the ''Super Slide'', is a {{convert|40|ft|m|adj=on}} vertical drop water slide attraction. The [[tort]] lawsuit filed sought $9,200 in medical costs and at least $50,000 in [[damages]] on behalf of one girl, age 11. The suit also sought $5,300 in medical costs and at least $100,000 in damages on behalf of the other girl, age 12. The park was charged with [[negligence]], failure to monitor the amount of force of the water and its effect on riders, failure to fix defects, and failure to provide adequate warnings to riders.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.rideaccidents.com/1999.html#mar2 |title = Knoebels water slide brings injuries, lawsuits |publisher = Ride Accidents |date = 1999-03-02 |accessdate = 2007-01-04 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120101134450/http://www.rideaccidents.com/1999.html#mar2 |archivedate = 2012-01-01 |df = }}</ref>
==Krug Park== {{main article|Krug Park (Omaha)#Roller coaster incident}}
===Big Dipper=== *On July 24, 1930, sometime after 6:00 p.m., the park's ''Big Dipper'' roller coaster crashed when a bolt worked itself loose. Four cars containing children and teenagers plunged to the ground. Four people were killed and 17 injured.<ref>[http://www.rcdb.com/pd1125.htm "Krug Park"]. Roller Coaster Database. Retrieved 2007-09-08.</ref><ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.ketv.com/150thbirthday/3243422/detail.html |title = Survivor Recounts Krug Park Tragedy |publisher = KETV |year = 2004 |accessdate = 2008-08-08 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120207175310/http://www.ketv.com/150thbirthday/3243422/detail.html |archive-date=2012-02-07 }}</ref><ref>Kucirek, M.L. (2004) ''Omaha's Krug Park Roller Coaster Accident: Exploring the Diffusion of Communication in Newspaper and Among Omaha Residents.'' University of Nebraska at Omaha. p 8. Retrieved 9/9/07.</ref><ref>[http://memories.ne.gov/cdm/ref/collection/opl/id/173 "Krug Park"]. Nebraska Library Commission. Retrieved 9/9/07.</ref>
==Lagoon Amusement Park== {{main article|Lagoon Amusement Park}}
===Roller Coaster=== {{Main article|Roller Coaster (Lagoon)}} *In 1934, a 20-year-old man from Ogden, Utah fell to his death as he attempted to stand up when the train was on its highest hill. He hit a number of support trestles on the way down. *In 1946, a man was struck by the train as he was working on scaffolding on the ride. He suffered skull, leg and arm fractures, as well as internal injuries, and died at a Salt Lake hospital on September 1, 1946. *On June 12, 1989, a 13-year-old girl stood up and fell {{convert|35|ft|m}} to her death. She was pronounced dead at the scene.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/50767/BOUNTIFUL-GIRLS-DEATH-NOT-THE-1ST-ON-LAGOONS-WOODEN-ROLLER-COASTER.html | title=BOUNTIFUL GIRL'S DEATH NOT THE 1ST ON LAGOON'S WOODEN ROLLER COASTER | work=[[Deseret News]] | date=13 June 1989 | accessdate=10 November 2013 | author=Rosebrock, Don}}</ref>
===Puff The Little Fire Dragon=== *On April 30, 1989, a 6-year-old boy attempted to exit the vehicle near the end of the ride. He was run over and killed by an oncoming train.<ref>{{cite news|author=Don Rosebrock|title=POLICE PROBING DEATH OF BOY KILLED ON LAGOON KIDDIE RIDE|url=https://www.deseretnews.com/article/44520/POLICE-PROBING-DEATH-OF-BOY-KILLED-ON-LAGOON-KIDDIE-RIDE.html| publisher=Deseret News|accessdate=9 August 2014|date=1989-05-01}}</ref>
==Lake Compounce==
{{main article|Lake Compounce}} ===The Tornado=== * On August 20, 1999 a 16-year-old park employee was knocked over and then crushed by the Tornado ride. The employee died from his injuries 10 hours later.<ref>{{cite news|author=MARYELLEN FILLO And JOHN SPRINGER|title=Amid The Grief, Warm Memories Of Teenager|url=http://articles.courant.com/1999-08-23/news/9908230065_1_richard-bisi-ride-hartford-hospital| publisher=Hartford Courant|accessdate=11 August 2018|date=1999-08-23}}</ref>
===Lake Plunge=== * On July 1, 2000 a 6-year-old boy had fallen into the lake when the tube he had used on the Lake Plunge water slide had overturned. The boy was found unconscious after a twenty-minute search and died six days later as a result of the injuries. In response, Lake Compounce made stricter safety precautions and made life jackets a requirement for children. <ref>{{cite news|title=Lake Compounce changes policy in wake of drowning|url=https://www.middletownpress.com/news/article/Lake-Compounce-changes-policy-in-wake-of-drowning-11933352.php| publisher=TheMiddleTownPress|accessdate=11 August 2018|date=2000-07-10}}</ref>
===Boulder Dash=== {{main article|Boulder Dash (roller coaster)}} * On June 13, 2001, A train from the Boulder Dash rollercoaster ride was sent on a {{convert|60|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} preliminary run when it struck and killed a 23-year-old groundkeeper who had been cutting weeds by the side of the ride.<ref>{{cite news|author=MARYELLEN FILLO And JOHN SPRINGER|title=Amid The Grief, Warm Memories Of Teenager|url=http://articles.courant.com/1999-08-23/news/9908230065_1_richard-bisi-ride-hartford-hospital| publisher=Hartford Courant|accessdate=11 August 2018|date=1999-08-23}}</ref>
===Miniature Golf Course=== * On May 16, 2004, a 5-year-old boy was killed when he was struck by a fallen tree branch from a decaying 80-foot red oak tree that hung above the park's miniature golf course. <ref>{{cite news|author=Roberto Gonzalez|title=Family Sues Lake Compounce|url=http://articles.courant.com/2005-12-03/news/0512030015_1_tree-service-oak-tree-amusement-park| publisher=Hartford Courant|accessdate=11 August 2018|date=2005-12-03}}</ref>
==Lake Winnepesaukah==
{{Main article|Lake Winnepesaukah}} ===Boat Chute=== * On May 27, 2018, a woman broke her foot on the water ride. The park was fined $500 for not reporting this incident in a timely manner.<ref name="winnie1"/>
===Bumper Cars=== * On June 17, 2018, a 16-year-old suffered a minor injury while riding. The park reported this incident properly, but the news report for this item pointed out that the park was cited three times in three years for failing to report incidents.<ref name="winnie1"/>
===Wild Lightin'=== * On May 27, 2018, a 62-year-old woman injured her arm and head while riding. The park was fined $1000 for not reporting this incident in a timely manner.<ref name="winnie1">{{cite news |url=http://www.wrcbtv.com/story/38391355/lake-winnie-guest-injured-at-park-sunday |title=UPDATE: Another Lake Winnie guest injured on park ride |publisher=WRCB-TV |author=WRCB staff and Kate Smith |date=2018-06-18 }}</ref> * On June 10, 2018, a woman fell out of the ride vehicle when her legs slipped out from the lap bar. The guest had to have surgery to address a broken shoulder and upper arm. Inspectors did not find any fault with the ride.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.timesfreepress.com/news/breakingnews/story/2018/jun/27/investigator-no-malfunction-lake-winnie-roller-coaster-led-womans-fall-documents/473953/ |title=Investigator: No malfunction in Lake Winnie roller coaster that led to woman's fall |date=2018-06-27 |author=Tyler Jett |publisher=Times Free Press }}</ref> The park received a warning for the 15-hour delay in reporting this incident.<ref name="winnie1"/>
===Guest altercations=== * On April 19, 2003, a crowd disturbance described as a "near-riot" involving 500 to 700 youths took place outside the park in [[Rossville, Georgia|Rossville]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] after management decided to close the park 90 minutes early. [[Catoosa County]] Sheriff Phil Summers claimed the incident was caused by parents leaving their children unattended at the park with little or no money, thus unable to participate in the park's activities. When sporadic fighting began in the crowd, the decision was made to close the park early, which escalated the fighting. Law enforcement agencies from Georgia and [[Tennessee]] were dispatched to the scene when the crowd began to disrupt traffic on roads surrounding the park. After the incident, the park instituted a new policy of requiring visitors under 21 years of age to be accompanied by a parent or guardian. Visitors are also required to purchase some sort of admission.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.northwestgeorgianews.com/disturbance-prompts-lake-winnie-to-implement-tougher-policie-local-headline/article_ded391d4-f10c-58f4-a7cc-25844a4d9f4f.html |title = Disturbance prompts Lake Winnie to implement tougher policie |publisher = northwestgeorgianews.com |date = 2003-03-23 |accessdate = 2016-11-23 }}</ref>
==Longshan Amusement Park==
===Scream=== * On May 1, 2015, two guests were killed and three were injured when they were thrown off the attraction. This was the first day of operation for the ride, and witnesses stated that they believed the ride was started by ride operators before the guests were secured.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/peoplesdaily/article-3064055/The-shocking-aftermath-two-tourists-plunged-deaths-thrown-Chinese-amusement-park-ride-called-Scream.html |title= Two tourists flung to their death from brand new Chinese amusement ride after it was switched on before they'd been buckled in |date= 2015-05-01 |work= Daily Mail |author=Edward Chow and Darren Boyle }}</ref>
==Luna Park Sydney== {{main article|Luna Park Sydney}}
===Ghost Train=== {{further information|1979 Sydney Ghost Train fire}}
==Nickelodeon Universe== {{main article|Nickelodeon Universe}}
===SpongeBob SquarePants: Rock Bottom Plunge=== Between 2011 and 2012, eight people complained of injuries from the ride. Six people complained of neck injuries and two complained of back injuries.<ref>http://amusementsafety.org/park_safety12.asp#nickelodeon</ref>
===Tak Attack=== {{main article|Tak Attack}} *In April 1998, a dime-sized plastic nut came loose on ''The Mighty Axe'' (now called ''Tak Attack''), causing the ride to come to a stop with riders stuck upside down at the very top. The loose nut had interrupted the power to the seating platform. The five riders were stuck for about an hour before park mechanics were able to get them down.<ref>http://gyxe.com/schizophrenia/35-785-adv-news-camp-snoopy-visitors-trapped-upside-down-on-ride-read.shtml ADV-NEWS, Camp Snoopy visitors trapped upside down on ride. {{Dead link|date=November 2016}}</ref>
===Log Chute=== {{main article|Log Chute}} *On Saturday, August 1, 1998, a 12-year-old boy fell off the log chute. When the boat neared the top of the chute, the boy began to panic and reached outside of the log to grab a railing. The ride operator attempted to stop the ride, but the log had already begun its descent down the major drop. Losing his grip, he fell off the chute, falling onto the landscaping rocks. The boy died from his injuries. O.D. Hopkins Associates, Inc., the manufacturer of the ride, inspected it and found it was in proper working order. It was Camp Snoopy's first fatal accident.<ref>http://www.rideaccidents.com/1998.html RideAccidents.com 1998 Ride Accidents Reports and News</ref> *On November 4, 2007, a conveyor belt on the log chute malfunctioned, causing one log to crash into the other. However, there were only minor injuries. The ride was inspected and repaired, and then reopened on November 15, 2007.<ref>StarTribune [http://www.startribune.com/local/11821951.html Mall of America log chute ride reopens after malfunction] November 15, 2007 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080220081301/http://www.startribune.com/local/11821951.html |date=February 20, 2008 }}</ref>
===Screaming Yellow Eagle=== {{main article|Screaming Yellow Eagle}} *On Saturday, August 15, 1998, an 8-year-old girl died of a heart attack a week before her 9th birthday, after she rode the ''Screaming Yellow Eagle'' (now known as ''Danny Phantom Ghost Zone''), a rotating platform ride from Chance Rides. Her parents said she died from a heart attack because she had a history of heart problems for five years before her death. The ride was normally operating properly.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rideaccidents.com/1998.html#aug15|title=RideAccidents.com -- 1998 Accident Reports and News|publisher=}}</ref>
===Backyardigans Swing-Along=== *On May 14, 2008, four people were slightly hurt, suffering minor leg injuries when the ''Backyardigans Swing Along'' malfunctioned, apparently spinning faster than normal. The ride was shut down when it became apparent that it was malfunctioning and remained closed until maintenance crews found and fixed the problem.<ref>StarTribune [http://www.startribune.com/local/18960704.html?location_refer=Local%20+%20Metro MOA ride malfunctions, slightly injuring 2 adults, 2 children]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} May 14, 2008</ref><ref>TwinCities.com [http://www.twincities.com/ci_9262487 Two children, two adults injured on Mall of America ride] May 14, 2008</ref> On May 18, 2008, the ride was inspected and fixed. It reopened on May 19, 2008. {{Citation needed|date=May 2008}} *In April 2010, the Backyardigans Swing Along ride broke down and was suspended in the air for about 30 minutes. No one was hurt and everyone was brought down safely. The ride was tested and reopened the same day.
==Old Indiana Fun Park== {{main article|Old Indiana Fun Park}}
* On August 11, 1996, a 4-year-old girl was paralyzed from the chest down, and her 57-year-old grandmother was killed after the miniature train ride at the Old Indiana Fun Park derailed and overturned as it approached a curve. The two victims were crushed under the weight of the cars. An investigation showed that the train was traveling much faster than its design speed of {{convert|12|mph}}.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.lostindiana.net/html/old_indiana_fun_park.html |title = Old Indiana Fun Park |publisher = Lost Enterprises |date = 2001–2006 |accessdate = 2007-09-07 }}</ref>
==Overseas Chinese Town East==
===Space Journey=== * On June 29, 2010, six people were killed and ten were injured when a Space Shuttle-simulator ride called ''Space Journey'' fell to the ground in [[Shenzhen]], [[People's Republic of China|China]]. According to eyewitnesses, one of the ride's 12 cabins came loose in an explosion while spinning and collided with other cabins. Some cabins dropped {{convert|50|ft|m}} and ejected passengers. Another eyewitness claimed that a power shortage caused the accident.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.theepochtimes.com/n2/content/view/38383/ |last = Lin |first = Jane |title = Amusement Park Accident in Southern China Kills 6 |publisher = The Epoch Times |date = 2010-01-07 |accessdate = 2010-01-07 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100702153619/http://www.theepochtimes.com/n2/content/view/38383/ |archivedate = 2010-07-02 }}</ref>
==Playland== {{main article|Playland (New York)}}
===Dragon Coaster=== * In 1988, an 8-year-old girl choked to death while chewing gum on the ride.<ref name=PlaylandFatalities>{{Cite web|url=http://coaster-net.com/newsandreleases.php?action=displayitem&newsid=846 |title=Deaths at Playland |date=June 30, 2007 |accessdate=May 18, 2011 |publisher=[[COASTER-net.com]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080327051340/http://coaster-net.com/newsandreleases.php?action=displayitem&newsid=846 |archivedate=March 27, 2008 |df= }}</ref>
===Mind Scrambler=== * On May 22, 2004, a 7-year-old girl from [[New Rochelle, New York]] was killed when she fell out of the ride after her restraining bar opened.<ref name=PlaylandFatalities/><ref name="playland"/> * On June 29, 2007, a 21-year-old female park employee from [[White Plains, New York]] was killed<ref name="playland">{{cite news |url=http://wcbstv.com/topstories/local_story_180230719.html |title=Woman Dies Following Rye Playland Accident |publisher=WCBS TV |date=2007-06-29 |accessdate=2007-06-30 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070702163528/http://wcbstv.com/topstories/local_story_180230719.html |archivedate=2007-07-02 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> when the ride was started by a second employee while the victim was still assisting guests with their safety restraints. Park officials stated that a safety precaution (put in place after the 2004 ''Mind Scrambler'' incident) was not followed.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.nydailynews.com/news/2007/06/30/2007-06-30_worker_death_at_rye_playland_caused_by_s.html |title = Worker Death at Rye Playland caused by Safety Training Errors |publisher = NY Daily News |date = 2007-06-30 |accessdate = 2007-07-01 | location=New York | first=Jennifer | last=Peltz }}</ref> A report issued by the State's Labor Department on August 24, 2007 stated that the ride operators were running the ride improperly. The ride owner was cited for providing inadequate training. Due to this incident, the ''Mind Scrambler ''was closed.<ref name=PlaylandFatalities/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thejournalnews.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070826/NEWS02/708260356/1018 |title=Family seeks justice in woman's death at Playland |publisher=The Journal News |date=2007-08-26 |accessdate=2007-08-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927204732/http://www.thejournalnews.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20070826%2FNEWS02%2F708260356%2F1018 |archivedate=2007-09-27 |df= }}</ref>
===The Whip=== * On August 18, 1938, a 19-year-old boy was killed when he was hurled from the ride.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://coaster-net.com/newsandreleases.php?action=displayitem&newsid=846 |title=Deaths at Playland New York |publisher=COASTER-net.com |accessdate=2009-11-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080327051340/http://coaster-net.com/newsandreleases.php?action=displayitem&newsid=846 |archivedate=2008-03-27 |df= }}</ref>
===Ye Old Mill=== * On August 3, 2005, a 7-year-old boy from [[Norwalk, Connecticut]] died of blunt force trauma to the head after he climbed out of a boat on the ''Ye Old Mill'' ride, where he became trapped underwater by a conveyor belt.<ref name="playland"/> The victim's family sued the county that owned Playland, and on March 24, 2009, the defendants were ordered to pay US$1.25 million, as well as create a scholarship in the victim's name. The scholarship is awarded annually to the Playland employee who exhibits excellence in safety and customer service.<ref name=PlaylandFatalities/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.lohud.com/article/2009903240358 |title=Family to get $1.25M in Playland death suit |author=Jorge Fitz-Gibbon |date=2009-03-24 |publisher=The Journal News |accessdate=2009-03-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090330143350/http://www.lohud.com/article/2009903240358 |archivedate=March 30, 2009 }}</ref>
===Guest altercations=== * On July 4, 2006, a 43-year-old woman from [[Queens, New York]] drowned after walking into a 40-foot-deep man-made lake that is off-limits to swimmers. An autopsy showed the victim had a blood alcohol level well over the legal limit.<ref name=PlaylandFatalities/>
== Rockin' Raceway ==
===The Hawk===
*On March 14, 2004, a 50-year-old woman fell off of a pendulum-like ride, "The Hawk". Afterwards, Charles Stanley Martin, the park manager, was charged with second-degree murder and was subsequently convicted of reckless homicide.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Grinberg|first1=Emanuella|title=Amusement park manager found guilty of reckless homicide|url=http://www.cnn.com/2005/LAW/05/17/ctv.martin/|accessdate=21 April 2016|date=19 May 2005}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Amusement park death leads to Tennessee murder trial|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/nation/2005-05-10-tenn-ride_x.htm|accessdate=21 April 2016|date=10 May 2005}}</ref>
==Scandia Family Fun Center== {{main article|Scandia Amusements}} ===Sky Screamer=== * On May 5th 2018, a 20-year-old man and a 14-year-old boy were stranded for 45 minutes when the attraction became stuck with the riders {{convert|150|ft|m}} in the air when the attraction lost power. Firefighters were brought in to rescue the guests. The riders were not hospitalized<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nbclosangeles.com/news/local/Amusement-Park-Ride-Sky-Screamer-Stuck-Rescue-Victorville-479154403.html|title=Two Riders Stuck 160 Feet Above the Ground on Sky Screamer Ride|publisher=NBC Los Angeles |date=2018-05-09|author=Staff }}</ref>
== Schlitterbahn == {{main article|Schlitterbahn}}
===Schlitterbahn South Padre=== *On March 6, 2013, a 20-year-old seasonal employee at Schlitterbahn South Padre was fatally injured when an overhead gate slammed down and pinned him. He was left on life support for organ donation and later died from the injuries on March 11, 2013.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://portisabelsouthpadre.com/2013/03/08/web-exclusive-waterpark-employee-remains-critical/|title=WEB EXCLUSIVE: Waterpark employee remains critical|last=Editor|date=2013-03-09|website=Port Isabel-South Padre Press|access-date=2017-04-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://valleycentral.com/news/local/hospital-lifeguard-dies-after-accident-at-schlitterbahn|title=Hospital: Lifeguard dies after accident at Schlitterbahn|last=Staff|first=Action 4 News|work=KGBT|access-date=2017-04-08|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://portisabelsouthpadre.com/2013/03/11/update-schlitterbahn-employee-injured-in-accident-dies/|title=UPDATE: Schlitterbahn employee injured in accident dies|last=Editor|date=2013-03-11|website=Port Isabel-South Padre Press|access-date=2017-04-08}}</ref> OSHA investigated and fined Schlitterbahn for six safety violations related to the fatal incident.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://portisabelsouthpadre.com/2013/08/29/schlitterbahn-cited-96k-for-fatality/|title=Schlitterbahn cited $96k for fatality|last=Editor|date=2013-08-30|website=Port Isabel-South Padre Press|access-date=2017-04-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.osha.gov/pls/oshaweb/owadisp.show_document?p_table=NEWS_RELEASES&p_id=24660|title=2013 - 08/27/2013 - South Padre Island water park cited by US Department of Labor's OSHA for failing to protect workers from hazardous energy sources |publisher=Occupational Safety and Health Administration|website=www.osha.gov|language=en-us|access-date=2017-04-08}}</ref>
===Schlitterbahn Kansas City=== *On August 7, 2016, a 10-year-old boy was killed in the park while riding [[Verrückt (water slide)|Verrückt]], a water raft slide touted as the tallest in the world at the time of the incident. The boy was decapitated and died before reaching the bottom, and two other unrelated riders in the same raft sustained injuries. The ride was decommissioned and scheduled for dismantling. Although the park settled civil claims with all parties in 2016, a [[Wyandotte County, Kansas|Wyandotte County]] grand jury filed criminal indictments against the park and three current or former executive in 2018. The indictment accused the park and its employees of negligence, as well as concealing design flaws and other issues with the ride.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kansascity.com/news/local/article116542643.html|title=Schlitterbahn will close Verrückt water slide where 10-year-old boy was killed|work=The Kansas City Star.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kansascity.com/news/local/article94932532.html|title=Another family says raft on Schlitterbahn’s Verrückt went airborne on July ride|work=The Kansas City Star.}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/family-boy-killed-waterslide-speaks-hurting/story?id=45445546|title=Family of boy killed on water slide: 'We're still hurting'|last=News|first=A. B. C.|date=2017-02-14|website=ABC News|access-date=2017-04-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://fox4kc.com/2018/03/23/court-documents-detail-allegations-of-negligence-in-design-of-schlitterbahn-water-slide-that-killed-10-year-old/|title=Court documents detail alleged negligence in design of Schlitterbahn water slide that killed 10-year-old|date=2018-03-23|website=fox4kc.com|access-date=2018-03-23}}</ref><ref>[https://www.cnn.com/2018/03/27/us/schlitterbahn-waterpark-death-arrests/index.html Kansas water park executives charged with murder in boy's death]</ref>
==Siam Park (Thailand)== {{main article|Siam Park City}}
===Flume ride=== *On October 23, 2007, one woman was killed and five others injured when the ride vehicle fell {{convert|20|m}} to the ground from the top of the lift hill. Park management said that there was a drop in electric power, causing a water pump to fail to control sufficient water level on the ride.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.bangkokpost.com/breaking_news/breakingnews.php?id=122909 |title = One killed in Siam Park flume ride mishap |publisher = Bangkok Post |date = 2007-10-23 |accessdate = 2007-10-23 }}</ref>
===Super Spiral=== *On January 12, 2008, 28 children, ages 10 to 13, were injured when they spiraled down two meters to the ground after the final sections of the ''Super Spiral ''water slide collapsed.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2008/01/13/2137389.htm?section=world |title = Police probe slide collapse at Thai water park |publisher = ABC News |date = 2008-01-13 |accessdate = 2008-01-21 }}</ref>
==Storybook Land==
===Big Truck Ride=== * On May 8, 2011, the ride derailed as it came up on the first turn, causing cars to go off the track and fall two and a half feet to the ground, injuring two adults and one child. The cause was determined to be an internal component. Management decided to remove the ride, explaining, "We simply can't be sure about the precise cause of the failure and will not risk the safety of our patrons when we cannot be 100% certain that the ride can be made completely safe." It was replaced with an attraction called ''Workzone'', which opened in the summer of 2014.<ref name="The Press of Atlantic City">{{cite news|publisher=The Press of Atlantic City|date=2011-05-12|url=http://www.pressofatlanticcity.com/news/press/atlantic/storybook-land-to-remove-big-truck-ride-after-three-injured/article_f6225f04-7cbb-11e0-8150-001cc4c03286.html|title=Storybook Land to remove Big Truck ride after three injured}}</ref>
==Splash Adventure== {{main article|Splash Adventure}} * In 1999, when the park was called Visionland, five people were injured when a raft overturned.<ref name="The Birmingham News"/> * In 2001, when the park was called Visionland, a boat filled with park employees overturned when the employees rocked the boat. The establishment was shaken up but no one was injured.<ref name="The Birmingham News"/> * On August 4, 2009, when the park was called Alabama Adventure, a family of three and one other park visitor were injured when the ride's boat capsized. Witnesses said that the family's boat hit an empty boat and was overturned. The family was underwater for approximately 20 seconds.<ref name="The Birmingham News">{{cite news|publisher=''The Birmingham News''|date=2009-08-05|url=http://blog.al.com/spotnews/2009/08/four_slightly_injured_after_al.html|title=Four slightly injured after Alabama Adventure ride capsizes}}</ref> * On June 6, 2011, when the park was called Alabama Adventure, a fight broke out between several youths and spread throughout the park. One guest described it as a borderline riot. The Bessemer Police were called to the park and no more guests were allowed into the park. The incident was blamed on a "$10 before 10AM" promotional event that was mishandled by park staff.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.al.com/spotnews/2011/06/borderline_riot_at_alabama_adv.html|title='Borderline riot' at Alabama Adventure theme park sends police in, park guests out|work=AL.com}}</ref> * On June 3, 2018, a 10-year-old boy was injured when he hit his head while floating around Warrior River.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbs42.com/news/local/child-hospitalized-after-sustaining-injury-at-alabama-splash-adventure-park/1218294029|title=Child hospitalized after sustaining injury at Alabama Splash Adventure park|work=cbs42.com}}</ref>
==Water Works Park== *On August 5, 2007, an unidentified 10-year-old girl suffered severe internal injuries while riding the speed slide at the [[Denton, Texas]] park. The accident report filed by the on-duty lifeguards stated that the injuries were caused by the victim's failure to follow park rules, namely keeping her legs crossed at the ankles, while riding.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/news/localnews/stories/082507dnmetslide.2bf47dc.html |title = Girl's injuries at Denton water park could prompt legal action |publisher = Denton Record-Chronicle |date = 2007-08-24 |accessdate = 2007-08-27 }}</ref> The park rule regarding crossing ankles on a [[water slide]] is common in the industry, and is one method (along with wearing a wet suit) used to prevent "straddle injuries."<ref>{{cite journal | author = Kuensting, Laura L. MSN(R), RN, CPNP |date=April 2007 | title = Water Park Injuries: A Literature Review | journal = [[Advanced Emergency Nursing Journal]] | volume = 29 | issue = 2 | pages = 151–157 | url = http://www.aenjournal.com/pt/re/tme/abstract.01261775-200704000-00010.htm;jsessionid=GTyJQvWQKvd12cKTPv1nj9vMGyp1qKwPcQHKk2czyNNcz0DqMG3b!-79285651!181195629!8091!-1 | accessdate = 2007-08-27 | doi = 10.1097/01.TME.0000270338.11756.08 }}</ref>
==The Wave== ===Emerald Plunge=== * On May 27, 2017, a 10-year-old boy hydroplaned off the water slide during the park's grand opening weekend, suffering injuries to his back.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.mercurynews.com/2017/05/27/video-child-thrown-from-the-wave-water-park-slide-in-dublin-on-opening-day/ |title=Video: Child thrown from The Wave water park slide in Dublin on Opening Day |publisher=Mercury News |author=Matthias Gafni |date=2017-05-27 }}</ref>. The victim's family settled with the slide's manufacturer for US$2.5 million. According to the father, the slide had been tested for height, not weight.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://abc7news.com/society/dublin-water-slide-reopens-following-terrifying-accident/3525465/ |title=Dublin water slide reopens following terrifying accident |date=2018-05-26 |publisher=ABC7 |author=Cornell Barnard }}</ref>
==World Waterpark== {{main article|World Waterpark}} ===Corkscrew=== *On August 5, 2018, a 59-year-old woman from [[Saskatoon, Canada]] who was at the park for her granddaughter's 5th birthday was sliding down the Corkscrew water slide when her ring got stuck on a piece of foam. The slide was shut down for inspection while a lifeguard helped find the missing ring and her finger which was torn off. Her finger was amputated while the park investigated the incident.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/edmonton/west-edmonton-mall-water-park-finger-injury-1.4784050|title=Woman's finger amputated after injury at West Edmonton Mall water park|date=2018-08-05|accessdate=2018-08-05|publisher=CBC.ca}}</ref>

<!-- Definition and symptoms --> '''Measles''' is a highly contagious [[infectious disease]] caused by the [[measles virus]].<ref name=MM2014>{{cite web|title=Measles|website=Merck Manual
